summary: c-di-GMP is a potent cytosolic inducer of type I IFNs. we compared the ability of overlayed versus transfected c-di-GMP to induce type I IFN in bone marrow macrophages. c-di-GMP is a potent cytosolic inducer of type I IFNs. c-di-GMP, treated or untreated with snake venom phosphodiesterase, was transfected at 3.3 g/ml into B6 bone marrow macrophages. c-di-GMP, treated or untreated with snake venom phosphodiesterase, was transfected at 3.3 g/ml into B6 bone marrow macrophages. each dot represents a single gene, and its position is determined by its induction in response to DNA (x axis) or c-di-GMP (y axis) most genes lie on the diagonal, indicative of similar induction ratios by both treatments. phosphodiesterase treatment of c-di-GMP resulted in a product that is no longer stimulatory. c-di-GMP is sensed in the cytosol, resulting in a potent induction of type I IFN in bone marrow macrophages. c-di-GMP signals independently of cytosolic DNA. HEK293 cells stably transfected with various TLRs failed to respond to c-di-GMP. but the reason for this failure was unclear. we tested responses in Myd88/Trif/double-knockout macrophages.
